links.description: Sanjuro‘s fake blood was a mix of chocolate syrup, for colour, and carbonated water, for movement. While Australian zombie flick Little Monsters also used a commercial drink (instant coffee) as a blood stand-in, it was for the opposite effect – to be as gritty as possible.

end.title: Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice
end.brief_description:
“Carve your own clever path to vengeance in an all-new adventure from developer FromSoftware.

Explore late 1500s Sengoku Japan, a brutal period of constant life and death conflict, as you come face to face with larger than life foes in a dark and twisted world. Unleash an arsenal of deadly prosthetic tools and powerful ninja abilities while you blend stealth, vertical traversal, and visceral head to head combat in a bloody confrontation.

Take Revenge. Restore your honor. Kill Ingeniously.”

links.description: From Software’s love letter to traditional Japanese combat, Sekiro, uses bursts of blood as a key part of the game mechanic, combining the release of figurative pressure (from defeating an enemy) with the release of literal pressure (of blood).

links.description: Edie Kurzer’s costume design for Judy & Punch involved several tests to ensure the fake blood on Judy’s showed up correctly on camera. In Kimberley Pierce’s Carrie, many tests of the iconic blood scene were done, to make it flow as perfectly as possible.

links.description: The high-gloss, flowing blood of Carrie calls to mind the ‘Elevator of Blood’ sequence from The Shining, which also involved weeks of preparation. Stanley Kubrick couldn’t bring himself to watch the sequence being filmed, in case something went wrong.

end.creator_credit: Charles Mulvehill, Francis Ford Coppola, Fred Fuchs, Roman Coppola and James V. Hart
end.brief_description: Gary Oldman, Sir Anthony Hopkins, Winona Ryder and Keanu Reeves star in Francis Ford Coppola’s adaptation of Bram Stoker’s Dracula. Featuring iconic performances, imaginative costumes and breathtaking cinematography, Coppola’s version breathed new life into the legendary tale.

links.description: To get the ‘Elevator of Blood’ sequence past the censors, Kubrick claimed that the red liquid was actually cordial. In Bram Stoker’s Dracula, Francis Ford Coppola makes the blood look as inviting and drinkable as possible… like cordial.

links.description: Creating the dramatic flow of blood in The Shining involved maintaining the pressure of the blood inside the elevator. For the iconic blood in Sanjuro, Kurosawa used a hose of blood so high-pressured that actor Tatsuya Nakadai was nearly knocked off his feet.
